**Reese 's Peanut Butter Cups** are a popular American [candy](/wiki/Candy_bar
"Candy bar") consisting of a milk, white, or dark [chocolate](/wiki/Chocolate
"Chocolate") cup filled with [peanut butter](/wiki/Peanut_butter "Peanut
butter"), marketed by [The Hershey Company](/wiki/The_Hershey_Company "The
Hershey Company"). They were created in 1928 by [H. B.
Reese](/wiki/H._B._Reese "H. B. Reese"), a former [dairy
farmer](/wiki/Dairy_farmer "Dairy farmer") and shipping foreman for [Milton S.
Hershey](/wiki/Milton_S._Hershey "Milton S. Hershey"). Reese was inspired by
Hershey and left dairy farming to start his own candy business.

## The H.B. Reese Candy
Company[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: The H.B. Reese Candy Company")]

**The Harry Burnett Reese Candy Co.** was established in the basement of
Reese's house in [Hershey, Pennsylvania](/wiki/Hershey,_Pennsylvania "Hershey,
Pennsylvania").[2] Reese had originally worked at a Hershey dairy farm, and
from the start he used Hershey Chocolate in his confections. Reese's Peanut
Butter Cups were his most popular candy, and Reese eventually discontinued his
other lines.

Reese died on May 16, 1956, passing the company to his six sons, Robert, John,
Ed, Ralph, Harry, and Charles Richard Reese. On July 2, 1963, the Reese
brothers merged the H.B. Reese Candy Company with the Hershey Chocolate
Corporation in a tax-free stock-for-stock merger with the six Reese brothers
receiving 666,316 Hershey common shares, valued in 1963 at $23.5 million. In
2017, after 54 years of stock splits, those original shares now represent
sixteen million Hershey common shares valued in excess of $1.7 billion, paying
$42 million in annual cash dividends.[3] The H.B. Reese Candy Company is
maintained as a subsidiary of Hershey because the Reese plant workforce is not
unionized, unlike the main Hershey plant. As of September 20, 2012, Reese's is
the best-selling candy brand in the United States with sales of $2.603
billion, and is the fourth-best-selling candy brand globally with sales of
$2.679 billion—only $76 million (2.8%) of its sales are from outside the
United States market. Additionally, the H.B. Reese Candy Company manufactures
the [Kit Kat](/wiki/Kit_Kat "Kit Kat") in the United States, which had 2012
U.S. sales of $948 million.[4]

##
Variations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Variations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Reeses-PB-Cups-Size-
Trio.jpg/250px-Reeses-PB-Cups-Size-Trio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reeses-PB-Cups-Size-
Trio.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reeses-PB-Cups-Size-Trio.jpg "Enlarge")

A trio of different sized cups. Starting from the left: mini, regular and big
cup.

Hershey's produces "limited editions" of the candy that have included:[5]

  * **Big Cups** : an oversized version of the traditional cup (also available in white chocolate, with peanuts, mixed nuts, and with a combination of nuts and caramel, and most recently, with [Reese's Pieces](/wiki/Reese%27s_Pieces "Reese's Pieces") inside)
  * **Caramel** : the traditional cup with an added layer of caramel filling
  * **Chocolate Lovers** : a thicker chocolate cup with a thinner layer of peanut butter
  * **Crunchy Cookie Cup** : a layered cup with crushed chocolate cookies and peanut butter filling (discontinued in 1999, but was brought back in 2008 as a limited edition. In 2017, Reese's announced to relaunch a new version.[6])
  * **Crunchy** : a traditional cup with crunchy peanut butter, as opposed to the smooth peanut butter in the original
  * **Dark Chocolate** : peanut butter filling in a [dark chocolate](/wiki/Dark_chocolate "Dark chocolate") cup
  * **Double Chocolate** : chocolate fudge filling instead of peanut butter. Limited edition.
  * **Double Crunch** : a traditional cup with peanut filling similar to a [Snickers](/wiki/Snickers "Snickers") bar, released in the fourth-quarter of 2010
  * **Fudge** : a thicker, darker chocolate cup with peanut butter filling
  * **Half-Pound Cup** : a single cup weighing 226g; released in Canada in 2011
  * **Hazelnut Cream** : [hazelnut](/wiki/Corylus_avellana "Corylus avellana") cream instead of the standard peanut butter filling
  * **Honey Roasted** : a traditional cup substituting honey roasted peanut butter
  * **Inside Out** : chocolate filling in a peanut butter cup (a reversal of the traditional version)
  * **Marshmallow** : the traditional cup with an added layer of [marshmallow](/wiki/Marshmallow "Marshmallow") filling
  * **Miniatures** : bite-size versions available year-round in bags. These chocolates come wrapped in black paper and gold foil.
  * **Minis** : Unwrapped Mini Cups
  * **Peanut Butter & Banana Creme**: a layered cup with a top chocolate layer, bottom [banana](/wiki/Banana "Banana") creme layer, and peanut butter filling; released in tribute to [Elvis Presley](/wiki/Elvis_Presley "Elvis Presley"). It was available in standard, Big Cups and Miniatures sizes
  * **Peanut Butter Lovers** : a layered cup with top peanut butter layer, thin chocolate layer and peanut butter filling
  * **White Chocolate** : peanut butter filling in a [white chocolate](/wiki/White_chocolate "White chocolate") cup
  * **" World's Largest"**: World's largest cups weighing in at 8 oz each.[7]

## Other Reese's
products[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Other Reese's products")]

Other candy products of the Reese's division of Hershey include:

  * **100 Calorie Peanut Butter Wafer Bars**
  * **Chips Ahoy With Reese 's Peanut Butter Cups**
  * **Reese 's Bar**: a chocolate bar with squares of chocolate with a peanut butter filling
  * **Reese 's [Brownies](/wiki/Chocolate_brownie "Chocolate brownie")**
  * **Reese 's Cookies**
  * **Reese 's Crunchy Cookie Cups**
  * **Reese 's Cremes**
  * **[Reese's Crispy Crunchy Bar](/wiki/Reese%27s_Crispy_Crunchy_Bar "Reese's Crispy Crunchy Bar")**
  * **[Reese's Fast Break](/wiki/Reese%27s_Fast_Break "Reese's Fast Break")**
  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Reeses-PB-Cups-Minis.jpg/220px-Reeses-PB-Cups-Minis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reeses-PB-Cups-Minis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reeses-PB-Cups-Minis.jpg "Enlarge")

Reese's Peanut Butter Cups Minis.

**Reese 's Mini's**

  * **Reese 's No Bake Bars**
  * **Reese 's [NutRageous](/wiki/NutRageous "NutRageous")**
  * **Reese 's Oreos**
  * **Reese 's Peanut Butter Bars** (with either chocolate or [fudge](/wiki/Fudge "Fudge") coating)
  * **Reese 's Peanut Butter Bites**
  * **Reese 's Pieces with Nuts**
  * **[Reese's Pieces](/wiki/Reese%27s_Pieces "Reese's Pieces")**
  * **Reese 's Pieces Cup**
  * **[Reese's Puffs](/wiki/Reese%27s_Puffs "Reese's Puffs") Cereal**
  * **Reese 's Select Cluster**
  * **Reese 's [Snack Barz](/wiki/Snack_Barz "Snack Barz")**
  * **Reese 's Two Packs**
  * **[Reese's Whipps](/wiki/Reese%27s_Whipps "Reese's Whipps")**
  * **Reese 's [Swoops](/wiki/Swoops "Swoops")**
  * **[Reese's Sticks](/wiki/Reese%27s_Sticks "Reese's Sticks")**
  * **Selecta Ice Cream With Reese 's Peanut Butter Cups** (sold in only in the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"))
  * **Sweet 'n' Salty Bar** Reese's Peanut Butter Cups **_(sold in[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") only)_**
  * **Breyer 's ice cream with Reese's flavor and chocolate and peanut butter pieces.**

In September 2007, Hershey's began producing a new Reese's bar called **Reese
's Whipps**. Featuring peanut butter-flavored [nougat](/wiki/Nougat "Nougat")
with a chocolate coating, it has been likened to a peanut butter-flavored [3
Musketeers](/wiki/3_Musketeers_\(confectionery\) "3 Musketeers
\(confectionery\)") candy bar owned by [Mars,
Incorporated](/wiki/Mars,_Incorporated "Mars, Incorporated").[8]

Hershey also produces several "pantry" items under the Reese's brand, such as
Reese's peanut butter chips (analogous to [chocolate
chips](/wiki/Chocolate_chip "Chocolate chip") for baking), Reese's premier
baking pieces (tiny cup-shaped pieces of chocolate filled with peanut-butter,
also for baking), Reese's jarred peanut butter, and Reese's toppings
(including peanut butter syrup, peanut butter and chocolate topping, and
Reese's [Magic Shell](/wiki/Magic_Shell "Magic Shell")) and
[sprinkles](/wiki/Sprinkles "Sprinkles") for [ice cream](/wiki/Ice_cream "Ice
cream").

For the July 2008 release of the [Batman](/wiki/Batman "Batman") feature film
_[The Dark Knight](/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_\(film\) "The Dark Knight \(film\)")_
, Reese's released two limited time products: blue and black Reese's Pieces
with Batman's likeness on the packaging, and Reese's peanut butter-filled
chocolate Batman logos which were sold individually and roughly the size of
two Reese's cups combined.[9][10]

The fact that Reese Sticks digressed from the normal Reese's naming pattern
was pointed out by Paul Lukas in his zine _Beer Frame_.[11] As Lukas noted,
even though the official name was Reese Sticks, most people he casually
surveyed pronounced it unknowingly as _Reese 's Sticks_. In 2009, Hershey's
changed the name officially to _Reese 's Sticks_.

### Holiday
editions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Holiday editions")]

During the seasons when retailers offer holiday-themed candies, Reese's Peanut
Butter candies are available in various shapes that still offer the standard
confection theme of the traditional Reese's cup (peanut butter contained in a
chocolate shell). They are sold in a 6-pack packaging configuration but are
usually available individually. Although exterior packaging is altered to
reflect the theme of the representative holiday, the actual holiday itself is
never presented.[12]

**Reese 's Peanut Butter Hearts**

Available mainly during January and February, these are heart-shaped
confections representing [Valentine's Day](/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day
"Valentine's Day"). At various retailers, an individually-packaged, larger
heart is available as well. These are packaged in all-red exterior packaging.

**Reese 's Peanut Butter Eggs**

Available mainly during March and April, these are egg-shaped confections
representing [Easter](/wiki/Easter "Easter"). Exterior packaging is usually
yellow and orange (milk chocolate), white and orange (white chocolate), or
dark brown and orange (fudge-flavored chocolate). This is the only holiday-
themed item available in three various chocolate varieties.[13] A larger,
individually-packaged [Easter Bunny](/wiki/Easter_Bunny "Easter Bunny")
Reese's peanut butter item, known as Reester Bunny, is available as well.
Also, Reese's Pieces are offered in Pastel Eggs.

**Reese 's Peanut Butter Pumpkins**

Available mainly during September and October, these are pumpkin-shaped
confections representing [Halloween](/wiki/Halloween "Halloween"). The
packaging is standard Reese's orange with a [jack-o-lantern](/wiki/Jack-o-
lantern "Jack-o-lantern") picture and the word "Pumpkins" prominently
displayed.

**Reese 's Peanut Butter Ghosts**

Available mainly during September and October, these are ghost-shaped
confections representing [Halloween](/wiki/Halloween "Halloween"). The
packaging is Halloween themed with the word scary on it. The ghost replaces
the letter "a" in the word scary. First released in 2016.

**Reese 's Peanut Butter Christmas Trees**

Available mainly during November and December, these are evergreen tree-shaped
confections representing [Christmas](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas"). At various
retailers these may be available in standard milk chocolate or white.
Initially, the packaging was green, white, and orange, but has been changed to
a winter scene with a snow-covered ground and a snowman with a central large
orange evergreen tree-shape in the center of the package. Another product
offered is Reese's Peanut Butter Bells, which offers miniature Reese's cups in
a Christmas bell shape. A third product is a milk chocolate-covered Reese's
Snowman, wrapped in a snowman foil. The peanut butter snowman is three times
larger than the peanut butter tree, egg or pumpkin.[14]

In December 2005, it was noted that some of the holiday shaped Reese's candies
(such as the Bells) contain [gluten](/wiki/Gluten "Gluten"), unlike the
standard peanut butter cups.[15]

In November 2015, consumers criticized the product via [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter
"Twitter") for bearing too vague a resemblance to a Christmas tree.[16]

### Licensed
foods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Licensed foods")]

Hershey licenses the Reese's brand (name, [logo](/wiki/Logo "Logo"), etc.) to
various companies for the production of other products beyond the traditional
realm of candy. For example, [General Mills](/wiki/General_Mills "General
Mills") produces [Reese's Puffs](/wiki/Reese%27s_Puffs "Reese's Puffs"), a
brand of peanut butter and chocolate flavored [breakfast
cereal](/wiki/Breakfast_cereal "Breakfast cereal"). Several companies,
including [Breyers](/wiki/Breyers "Breyers"), [Baskin-Robbins](/wiki/Baskin-
Robbins "Baskin-Robbins"), and [Dairy Queen](/wiki/Dairy_Queen "Dairy Queen"),
produce various licensed Reese's ice cream products.

## Marketing and
advertising[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Marketing and advertising")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/53/Reese%27s_logo.svg/220px-
Reese%27s_logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Reese%27s_logo.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Reese%27s_logo.svg "Enlarge")

The Reese's logo

In the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), Reese's Peanut
Butter Cups typically come in packs of 2, 4, 5, 10 or 20 in distinctive orange
packaging, set on thin but rigid [paperboard](/wiki/Paperboard "Paperboard")
trays. The "Classic" two-pack is a 0.75 oz. cup since 2001 (originally a 0.9
oz. size, reduced to 0.8 oz. in 1991), the "King Size" four-pack introduced in
the early 1980s is a 0.7 oz. cup (originally a 0.8 oz. cup until 1991) and the
"Lunch" eight-pack is a 0.55 oz. cup. "Large Size" packs of three 0.7 oz.
cups, as well as bags containing 0.6 oz. cups, are also available. The "mini"
cups come in various bag sizes and foil colors for seasonal themes like red,
gold and green for the Christmas holiday season. In [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada"), where they are packaged as **Reese Peanut Butter Cups** (except
Reese's pieces), but still widely referred to by their American name, they
come in a standard pack of three 0.55 oz. cups or the king-size variation with
four cups. In the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") and
[Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"), they were
originally available only in two-packs, though are now only available in
three-packs, imported from Canada. In 2008 Reese's Peanut Butter Cups were
made available in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") by [Hydro
Texaco](/wiki/Hydro_Texaco "Hydro Texaco") and [7-Eleven](/wiki/7-Eleven
"7-Eleven"). In Australia, Reese's products can be found in many specialty
candy stores, as well as from American stores such as [Costco](/wiki/Costco
"Costco").

In the 1970s and 1980s, a series of commercials were run for Reese's Peanut
Butter Cups featuring situations in which two people, one eating [peanut
butter](/wiki/Peanut_butter "Peanut butter") and one eating
[chocolate](/wiki/Chocolate "Chocolate"), collided. One person would exclaim,
"You got your peanut butter on my chocolate!" and the other would exclaim,
"You got your chocolate in my peanut butter!". They would then sample the
mixture and remark on the great taste, tying in with the [slogan](/wiki/Slogan
"Slogan") "Two great tastes that taste great together."

In the 1990s, the product's slogan was: "There's no wrong way to eat a
Reese's." The current slogan, introduced in the mid-2000s, is: "Perfect".

Reese's was an associate sponsor of [Monster Energy NASCAR Cup
Series](/wiki/Monster_Energy_NASCAR_Cup_Series "Monster Energy NASCAR Cup
Series") drivers [Mark Martin](/wiki/Mark_Martin "Mark Martin") (1994), and
[Kevin Harvick](/wiki/Kevin_Harvick "Kevin Harvick") (2007–2010).

##
Criticism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Reese%27s_Peanut_Butter_Cups&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Criticism")]

Reese's Peanut Butter Cups are made with the controversial ingredient PGPR
([Polyglycerol polyricinoleate](/wiki/Polyglycerol_polyricinoleate
"Polyglycerol polyricinoleate"), E476, a.k.a. Palsgaard 4150),[17] which is
used as a replacement for [cocoa butter](/wiki/Cocoa_butter "Cocoa
butter").[18] The FDA has determined it to be "safe for humans as long as you
restrict your intake to 7.5 milligrams per kilogram of body weight.
